awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: GEM--Comparing Simulations of Electron Acceleration in Kinetic Alfven Waves with Observations from the Van Allen Probes in the Inner Magnetosphere
awd_abstract_narration:
The focus of this project is study a class of waves known as kinetic Alfven waves (KAWs) that may play an important role in the formation of the aurora.  New observations from the Van Allen Probes mission show that these waves are a common during space weather storms.  Interactions between these KAWs and electrons can result in penetration of these electrons into the atmosphere.   Their penetration into the upper atmosphere leads to changes into electrical characteristics of the upper atmosphere.  Understanding the factors that control the electrical properties of the upper atmosphere is essential to producing better space weather forecasts.  The project will use a combination of numerical models and observations to investigate the process that transfers energy from the KAWs to the electrons.  Undergraduate and graduate students will actively participate in this project.  The investigators will also plan to provide opportunities for undergraduates to participate in the research through partnership with National Undergraduate Fellowship Program in Plasma Physics and Fusion Energy Sciences program.

The proposers will use a hybrid Gyrofluid-Kinetic-Electron (GKE) model to study the recently observed traveling and standing Alfven waves prevalent through the inner magnetosphere during substorms. Van Allen probes data will be used to derive simulation parameters and compare with simulation output. This investigation will determine how and to what extent KAW energy flux is converted to electron energy flux in the inner magnetosphere.  It will determine to what extent this mechanism is an efficient and effective pathway for enhanced energization and scattering of plasmasheet electrons into the loss cone, for additional heating of the ionosphere due to this scattering and for additional Poynting flux into the ionosphere.

por.por_cntn:
Observations from NASA's mission to the radiation belts, known as the Van Allen Probes, have provided an unprecedented view of interactions along the boundary between the quasi-steady region of near-Earth space dominated by Earth's magnetic field (inner magnetosphere), and those dynamic regions just outside. Measurements show that during space weather events (geomagnetic storms) this boundary is compressed, blurred and distorted as energetic plasmas are injected deep inside near-Earth space. At these times this region is pervaded by low frequency broad-band electromagnetic variations that carry energy along geomagnetic field lines and couple the upper reaches of Earth?s atmosphere to the dynamics taking place in space above. These fluctuations have been identified as Alfven waves - a specific mode of oscillation occurring in plasmas. A characteristic feature of the plasmas in which these waves are observed from the Van Allen Probes is the frequent occurrence of distributions of electrons that are enhanced along the geomagnetic field. These electrons precipitate into the upper atmosphere with energies extending up to kilo-electron Volts driving ionization and heating with macroscale consequences for the near-Earth space environment. This research characterized the properties of these electron distributions and explored the mechanisms driving their formation in the fluctuating fields in which they are observed.

The research was pursued as a collaborative effort between the University of Alaska at Fairbanks, where numerical simulations were performed, and the University of California at Berkeley where the analyses of the measurements from the Van Allen Probes and other assets including the Cluster spacecraft was pursued. This report pertains to the effort at the University of California and so primarily concerns outcomes from the analysis of measurements with reference to the simulation effort to support the conclusions drawn.

The analyses of measurements from the Van Allen probes revealed a robust statistical correlation between the occurrence of Alfvenic fluctuations and geomagnetic field-aligned fluxes of electrons. These correlations were performed over more than a year of Van Allen Probes observations to provide empirical relations (laws) describing the relationship between energy transport and energy density in Alfven waves and the characteristic energy, and energy flux of the electron distributions in which they are immersed.  These laws provide a statistical argument that Alfven waves play an important role in enhancing field-aligned electron distributions locally at the spacecraft while driving precipitation into the ionosphere at low latitudes during geomagnetic storms.

To characterize the operation of this process along the geomagnetic field combined observations from the Van Allen Probes and Cluster spacecraft when at similar geomagnetic locations, but different altitudes, were used. These studies revealed the coincident appearance of Alfvenic field variations and field-aligned electron distributions all along the geomagnetic field. It was shown in related study in part supported through this grant, that these observations are synchronous with the production of auroral luminosity at relatively low-latitudes thereby unambiguously connecting the Alfven wave - electron interaction in the inner magnetosphere to electron precipitation and energy deposition into the upper atmosphere.

To investigate how this works numerical simulations were performed. These provided insights into the interaction between Alfven waves and electrons that are not accessible from point measurements from spacecraft.  This was pursued using a gyrofluid-kinetic electron code capturing the self-consistent energy exchange between electromagnetic fields and electrons along the geomagnetic field between hemispheres and across latitudes. Multiple simulations runs were performed to encompass the observed range in plasma parameters with specific runs performed for case study events defined by the in-situ plasma and wavefield properties at a specific time and location. While we shall leave the physical details for our collaborators report, these simulations revealed how electron trapping and heating in the electric fields of the Alfven wave generates field-aligned electron distributions. Comparisons of the simulated evolution of the electron distributions to that observed at multiple points along the field-line as functions of energy and velocity with respect to the geomagnetic field confirmed the operation of this process.

In summary, this research has characterized and provided a physical explanation for field-aligned electron distributions prevalent through the inner magnetosphere during geomagnetic storms.  It should be noted that the energization and heating of these electrons by trapping in Alfven waves has implications beyond just explaining these specific observations. This is because it has been verified in a related study that these waves and more specifically, the precipitation of electrons into the upper atmosphere that these waves drive, stimulate flows of ions outward into the magnetosphere. This outflow will alter the inertia of plasmas through the inner magnetosphere with basic consequence for bulk plasma motions and the dynamics of this region of space during geomagnetic storms. The widespread micro-scale interactions between Alfven waves and electrons characterized through this research may therefore impact the global dynamics of Earth?s magnetosphere.
